topic.title: Using RSS Bandit from Multiple Computers

keywords.keyword: Using RSS Bandit from Multiple Computers

para.text: Using RSS Bandit from Multiple Computers

RSS Bandit now has rich support for synchronization across multiple computers (version 1.2.0.112 and greater). This comes in very handy when you use RSS Bandit on multiple computers such as from work and home.

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:11pt; font-weight:bold; text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000;

para.text: Why is this useful?

After a full day of work in which you spend some of that time reading feeds, it is a bit of an annoyance to come home and have to wade through all the items that you've already read to find the few new items you haven't yet read since you left work.

para.text: How does synchronization via a Web-based feed reader work?

When you launch RSS Bandit your feed list downloaded from the Web-based feed reader. Each time you make changes such as marking an item as read, subscribing to a new feed, removing a feed, or renaming a feed, this change is quickly reflected on the Web-based feed reader.
In addition, RSS Bandit periodically polls your Web-based feed reader so that if you make changes via the Web they are eventually reflected in RSS Bandit as well.

para.text: How does synchronization via remote storage work?

Sychronization data is transferred within a ZIP compressed file that contains information about the current state of your search folders, flagged items, replied items, subscribed feeds, and read/unread messages.
Please note that the actual feed content is not transferred, but rather the state of the feed content such as whether an item has been read or not.
For example, suppose you read the latest riveting post from
with the id

para.text: on your home computer. Being late for work, you hurriedly hit

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:11pt; font-weight:bold; text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000;

para.text: CTRL+SHIFT+U

to upload your current state. This uploads the fact that you've read item #123 on haack.org. It does not upload the actual content of item #123. Upon arriving at work and settling down with your morning coffee, you hit

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:11pt; font-weight:bold; text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000;

para.text: CTRL+SHIFT+D
to download your state, you may notice that item #123 does not show up. However, after refreshing your feeds by hitting

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:11pt; font-weight:bold; text-decoration:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000;

para.text: CTRL+F5
, RSS Bandit will download that item and it will appear as a read item rather than as a new item.
